title: Glyn Roberts: Tributes paid to north London lifeguard after sudden death on New Year's Day

organizations.name: parliament hill lido on hampstead heath

text:
Saturday 7 January 2017 07:32 BST Glyn Roberts was a popular figure in his local community 
Tributes have been paid to a well-liked lifeguard from north London who died suddenly on New Year’s Day. 
Glyn Roberts worked at the Parliament Hill Lido on Hampstead Heath for 25 years and was a hugely popular figure at the pool and in the Holloway community, where he lived all his life and frequently fought for local causes. 
The father-of-three was rushed to hospital with chest pains on January 1 but died that night aged 48. 
During his time at the lido he was responsible for saving a number of people’s lives, helping to resuscitate people after they came into difficulty in the water and on the Heath, friends said. 
Lido manager Paul Jeal worked with Mr Roberts since 1992, including on the day he died, and told the Standard he was a “wonderful man” and “loyal friend”. 
Well liked: Glyn Roberts, right, pictured at the Parliament Hill Lido where he worked 
Mr Jeal, 50, said: “He was very helpful to other people, he was a good loyal friend. 
“I have run 10 marathons with him, we have trained together, run together, with did the three peaks challenge together. 
“He was very fun, caring, helped everyone out. He will leave a big gap.” 
When news of his death emerged on January 2, the lido was closed and flowers and cards were laid at its gates, while the pool has now opened a book of condolences. 
Mr Roberts was also chairman of his local tenants and residents association and his local voluntary work included campaigning to protect green spaces and building a games area for children. 
He completed 15 marathons, raising thousands of pounds for charities. 
Friends said, despite his busy life – which included a number of other interests such as history and photography – he was always keen to help. 
'Wonderful man': Glyn Roberts, who completed the three peaks challenge, climbing Mount Snowdon 
Paul Nichols, 47, who knew Mr Roberts since they were children, said: “My father was hit by a lorry back in 2007. 
“I went straight to the place where he had been hit and the first person I saw was Glyn, who was part of the ambulance crew that day. 
“It was calming to see Glyn there who had been with my dad assuring him he would be alright. I owe him a lot." 
Tributes have also poured out for Mr Roberts on social media. 
Susanne Lamido wrote on Facebook: “Why do the good die young? Can't help crying, my special community buddy Glyn Roberts died this morning. 
“The local community loved him. He helped everybody and continually raised money for charity. RIP my friend.” 
Mr Roberts leaves his partner Victoria, son Edward and daughters Holly and Jessica. More about:
